keyTakeAways: The NBA season opens with a record 135 players born outside the U.S., representing 43 countries, with 71 from Europe — the most ever from that continent.
Canada leads with 23 non-U.S. players, followed by France (19) and Australia (13).
The Atlanta Hawks open with 10 international players, tying the NBA record.
All 30 NBA teams have at least one international player on their opening-night rosters.
The NBA is in talks with FIBA to launch a new European league as early as 2027, reflecting growing global interest in the sport.
The last seven NBA MVPs have been awarded to players born outside the U.S., marking a historic trend in global talent dominance.

Oklahoma City’s Shai Gilgeous-Alexander (Canadian) and players like Nikola Jokić (Serbia), Giannis Antetokounmpo (Greece), and Joel Embiid (Cameroon-born) have won the MVP award, highlighting the rise of international stars.
LeBron James is set to break multiple records during the season, including his 23rd season, 1,611 regular-season games, and 350 field goals made.
The Brooklyn Nets are considered one of the youngest rosters, with no player among the top 100 active scorers; their combined stats and experience are notably lower than established stars.
A new All-Star Game format is expected, featuring U.S. players facing off against international players in a tournament.

There are seven players with the last name 'Jordan' and five with the first name 'Nikola' and five with the first name 'James' in the opening rosters, highlighting naming trends and cultural influences.
Orlando Robinson is the only player reportedly wearing his first name on the front and last name on the back of his jersey, representing a unique personal branding moment.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The 2025 NBA season opens with a record number of international players—135 born outside the U.S. from 43 countries, including 71 from Europe, signaling a growing global presence. Canada leads with 23 non-U.S. players, followed by France and Australia. The Atlanta Hawks tie the NBA record with 10 international players on their roster. The NBA is in active talks with FIBA to launch a new European league as early as 2027, reflecting a strategic push to expand basketball's reach. The last seven MVPs have gone to players born outside the U.S., indicating a shift in global talent dominance. Key international stars like Nikola Jokić (Serbia), Giannis Antetokounmpo (Greece), and Shai Gilgeous-Alexander (Canada) are central to this trend. Meanwhile, the Brooklyn Nets are highlighted as one of the youngest rosters, lacking any top-100 scorer, while LeBron James continues to break records. A new All-Star Game format is expected, pitting U.S. players against international players in a tournament. The article also notes unique cultural trends, such as multiple players named Jordan, Nikola, and James, and the rare case of Orlando Robinson wearing his first name on the front of his jersey. These developments underscore the NBA’s growing global appeal and transformation into a truly international sport.
title: NBA Season 2025 Opens with Record International Players and Global Expansion Plans
